Honestly, I think the Catholic Church needs to make some changes to stay relevant.  I think one reason people are losing interest in the Church is because it isn't very open-minded when it comes to certain issues.  They have rigid views on things like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control, which are outdated in many ways.  If they adapted to a more modern way of thinking, I don't think they'd be worried about losing followers. 

I've heard many people are turning against the Catholic Church because of their stance on these issues.  People are starting to disagree with them on these topics, and that's causing some to question the Church's views.  They feel the Church is out of touch with modern values.  For example, if you support abortion rights, you might not feel comfortable being part of a community that sees it as morally wrong.  Similarly, if you're in favor of gay marriage, you might not want to be part of a group that disapproves of it.

I don't see why the Church can't allow female priests or have priests who are married.  It's not clear if that would have prevented scandals like the ones we've seen, but it's an idea worth considering.  It's hard to say whether allowing married priests or women priests would have made a difference, but it's worth exploring.  It's worth noting that other jobs involve balancing work and personal life – why can't priests do the same?

The Church views priests as married to God, devoted to a life of service.  However, most people in the world have a job and a family life, and they manage to balance both.  So, I don't see why priests can't have both a career and a family.

to be honest, i'm a bit hesitant to express my thoughts on the topic of gay marriage. let me just say that personally, i don't have an issue with it - i think people should be free to live their lives however they choose. it's not something that i think is a conscious choice, and if someone is born with a certain orientation, i don't think they should be held accountable for it. it doesn't sit right with me to think that a couple of the same sex shouldn't be allowed to get married just because of their orientation.

i think the key thing is that people are born the way they are, whether they're straight, gay, or whatever. it's not something that can be changed, and i don't think it's fair to judge someone for it. so, in my opinion, it's just wrong to deny people the right to get married based on their orientation.

i'm not sure if i've really given this topic much thought, but i think it's clear to me that it's not about making a choice, it's about being who you are. and i don't think the federal government should be involved in making decisions about people's personal lives.

it's just not their place to dictate how people live their lives, especially when it's something as fundamental as who they can marry. it's not a matter of national security or morality, it's just a matter of letting people be themselves. and if that means a same-sex couple wants to get married, then that's their choice, not the government's.

anyway, that's my two cents on the matter. i'm not sure if i've made myself clear, but i think it's pretty simple - people should be free to live their lives as they see fit, and the government should stay out of it.

I believe that gay marriage should be legalized because there's really no valid reason not to. The argument that homosexual couples pose a threat to the traditional family is just not convincing, considering the complexity of the issue. It's like comparing apples and oranges - they're two distinct entities that can't be reduced to simple opposition. The fact is, gay couples have the same fundamental rights as straight couples, including property rights and access to healthcare, which are essential for ensuring the well-being of all individuals.

However, when it comes to healthcare, gay couples often face unique challenges. For instance, their partners may not be recognized as family members, even if they're in a long-term committed relationship, which can limit their access to care and support. This seems unreasonable, especially considering the importance of having a supportive partner during times of illness.

Research has shown that gay couples are just as capable of forming stable and fulfilling relationships as straight couples. They share similar relationship dynamics, and their relationships are just as likely to succeed. The trouble is that many people are hung up on the idea that gay marriage is somehow against their religious beliefs or moral code. But if we're talking about a civil union, a legal document issued by the government, then what's the issue? It's not about church and state; it's about recognizing the rights of all citizens.

The concept of segregation, where certain groups are treated unequally, is a major concern here. It's similar to the old days of "separate but equal," which we've learned is fundamentally unfair. Gay couples are not asking for the right to get married in a church; they're seeking a marriage certificate, a legal document that recognizes their commitment to each other.

People worry about adoption issues, community acceptance, and the impact on children, but these concerns are often based on misconceptions and prejudices. Research suggests that children raised by gay parents are just as well-adjusted as those raised by straight parents. The real issue is how society treats these children, not their parents' sexual orientation. In fact, many schools and communities are working to create inclusive environments for these children, acknowledging that they deserve the same love, support, and respect as any other child.

The federal government should take a more prominent role in ensuring that gay marriage is recognized and protected nationwide. The proposed amendment to ban gay marriage is a step in the wrong direction, as it would impose a narrow, religious-based view on the entire country. This would be hypocritical, considering the recent controversy over the "under God" debate and the pledge of allegiance.

Many people are opposed to gay marriage due to misconceptions about the causes of homosexuality, such as childhood trauma or a personality defect. However, organizations like the American Psychological Association have debunked these claims, emphasizing the importance of evidence-based research over personal opinions and cultural norms. If we listened more to institutions that conduct rigorous studies and less to popular opinion, we might gain a more nuanced understanding of these issues.

Alright, so here's the thing, I work at the hospital pharmacy over the summer, and let's be real, just because a drug is outlawed doesn't mean it can't have some benefits. I'm saying no to making it available to the general public, no way, but using it for medicinal purposes? That's a different story. We use loads of controlled substances in pharmacies, like oxycodone, Vicodin, and Percocets, and they're super beneficial. So, just because marijuana is taboo doesn't mean we should deny its potential benefits.

It's not like these other controlled substances, either. If you abuse marijuana, it's not the same as abusing alcohol, which can lead to serious issues. It's a tough call, but I think we should allow it gradually, not all at once, because that would just lead to overuse. We need to break down the stigma surrounding marijuana first, and then people might start using it responsibly.

The issue is that people have this awful image of marijuana in their heads, which isn't entirely fair. It's not like heroin or cocaine; it's not that bad for you. If we can change that image, people might start using it for medical purposes, and who knows, responsibly.

i think the church has made an effort to adapt to modern times, but it's still not the strict institution it used to be.  growing up, i was a regular at church every sunday, dressing up in cute outfits, matching shoes, and a purse.  it was part of my routine, especially since i attended a private school where i saw my friends every weekend.  but over time, the church has changed, introducing a teenager mass that's just 30 minutes long and allowing more casual attire, even for the morning masses.  during the summer, people often show up in beachwear, and families often rush in late.  it's become a more relaxed atmosphere, with people wearing jeans and khakis instead of traditional church clothes.  while it's nice to see a more casual approach, it's still the church i know.  as for the church's internal politics, i'm not well-versed on the details, but that's my general observation.

regarding the accusations of pedophilia within the catholic church, i think these issues could've been avoided regardless of the church's policies on female priests or married priests.  in my opinion, pedophilia is more of a personal issue, and it's the individual's choice to become a priest.  there are already married men who become pedophiles, so allowing them to get married wouldn't necessarily solve the problem.  i also think that when someone chooses to become a priest, it's a personal decision, and they should consider a faith that allows them to be married if that's what they want.

to elaborate, i think pedophilia is more of a genetic issue than something someone develops due to their environment.  while upbringing might play a small role, i believe it's largely based on genetics.  you can't change someone's genetics through marriage, and it's unlikely they'll be able to hide their true nature.  if the church was aware of these issues and chose to cover them up, that's a different matter altogether.  however, i don't think they necessarily knew about every case.  overall, i don't have any other thoughts on the catholic church beyond this.

I'll be honest, my initial take on the whole situation was quite acceptable, but I think everyone was still reeling from the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks, and the invasion of Iraq was largely a pretext. I believe the Bush administration initially tried to link the Iraq war to Osama Bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks, claiming Saddam Hussein had WMDs, which has since been proven false.

To be frank, the fact that the Bush administration has been so open about lying to the American people really gets my blood boiling. Even Colin Powell, who presented the evidence at the UN, now admits he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time. That's a huge red flag in my book – it's essentially malfeasance in office, and I think it's an impeachable offense.

It seems to me that the administration has consistently disregarded the Constitution and tried to marginalize it since 9/11. They came into office with a clear intention to go to war, and I think the younger Bush had a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein due to his dad's administration's issues with him. On top of that, Bush's true motives seemed to be expanding our energy supply, which is a pretty underhanded way to do things.

Frankly, I think it's time to move on, but withdrawing now could lead to a civil war and more casualties. The alternative, which the UN and US are considering, is to form a coalition with neighboring countries like Syria and Saudi Arabia to restore order, but I'm not sure that's the best idea either. It'll likely lead to more problems down the line, especially with Iraq's sovereignty being a major issue. The interim government is essentially falling apart, and the Parliament is ineffective, with the Prime Minister having little control over the situation. Even Mugtada al-Sadr's party holds a significant amount of power, and we're still dealing with radical elements fighting for control. It's clear the political process is facing a lot of friction due to these factors.

To be blunt, I don't have any polite words for the whole situation.

i've been wanting to discuss my thoughts about the war in iraq for a while now, but to be honest, it's a really complicated topic for me. i guess you could say i'm still trying to wrap my head around it. one thing that's been on my mind is that it's not even a declared war, which kinda makes it hard to understand our presence over there. i feel like it was more of a retaliatory measure after the 9/11 attacks, and we've been staying in iraq to try and establish a democracy, which sounds great on paper, but it's not that simple. we're also trying to secure oil resources, which isn't a very compelling reason to stay. the problem is, we're just making things worse for everyone involved. if we stay, we'll have to invest a lot of time and money in building a democracy, which is a long-term commitment, and if we leave, the iraqis will be left to pick up the pieces and deal with the aftermath. it's a tough situation, and to be honest, i don't feel like i have a clear answer.

i've been thinking a lot about how we got into this situation and how we can get out of it. one thing that's been on my mind is that we never actually declared war in congress, so it's not even a 'real' war in the eyes of some people. i'm not sure what the point is in staying over there anymore, and it's making our country look bad in the eyes of the world. it's a bit like the vietnam war, which was also undeclared and is now seen as a pointless conflict. our president is getting a bad reputation because of it, and i feel bad for him, but ultimately, it's not just about him - it's about the people who are suffering in iraq.

i know some people have family members fighting over there, and it's hard to say that i want the war to end when i know how much it affects them. but at the same time, i'm worried that our presence is causing more harm than good. we're trying to impose our way of life on the iraqis, which isn't going to work, and it's only going to make them more resentful towards us. the whole al-qaeda thing is just going to get worse, and our efforts to establish a democracy are going to be a long, drawn-out process. i think this conflict is going to drag on for years to come, and i'm not sure what the end result will be.

Honestly, I'm not sure if I should even be having this conversation. But here's my take on it: I don't think it's right for a state to make it legal or even declare it as legal. I believe that's a decision that should be left up to the churches. The constitution clearly states the separation of church and state, and I think trying to enforce any kind of power over it would be a direct defiance of that.

In my opinion, the people pushing to make it illegal are essentially choosing one church's beliefs over another. Most Catholics and Christians are against it, except in certain areas. I don't think it's the government's job to decide what the churches can and can't make illegal.

The separation of church and state has been a cornerstone of the US constitution, allowing for religious tolerance. I think any attempt to make an amendment about it would be completely wrong and go against what's already been written. Plus, it would be one of the only amendments that restricts the people rather than the government. I don't think that's right at all.

I don't believe the federal government or any government should be involved in this issue. It seems to me that the president's push for this amendment is driven by his own personal Catholic beliefs, showing a clear preference for one religion over others. I think it's up to the churches to decide this, not the president or the government. There's no solid reason behind this amendment other than personal views, and I don't see how it would have any significant impact on the economy or society.

To be honest, I've said most of what I want to say on the matter.

Okay, so I'm thinking about the war in Iraq and I don't think the government was entirely honest with the American public about the reasons for going to war before invading Iraq. In my opinion, there was an attempt to link the invasion of Iraq to the 9/11 terrorist attacks, even though they're not closely related. The government played on the emotions of the American people following the 9/11 attacks and used that to justify the invasion in 2003.

Personally, I'm strongly against war, especially preemptive strikes, and I think the war in Iraq is a repeat of sorts of the Vietnam War. The government should have learned from its past mistakes and been better prepared for the aftermath of the invasion. A huge number of American soldiers have died, which is absolutely heartbreaking, and the US government wasn't prepared for the power vacuum and chaos that followed.

The US removed the Iraqi government and tried to establish a democratic one, similar to what they tried to do in Vietnam, but it's a much more complicated process than people initially thought. The government should have known that it would be a long and difficult ordeal, and not a clear-cut victory. In Vietnam, the US fought against an actual army, but in Iraq, they're fighting against citizens, which makes it even harder to put down the insurgency.

I think the government made a mistake by going to war without planning for all possible outcomes, and they weren't prepared for the consequences of removing the Iraqi government. We're still in Iraq today, and many American soldiers are still dying, and the US is still trying to train Iraqi troops and police to secure their own country. It's a long process, and I think the US government tried to deceive the American people into thinking it would be a quick and successful mission.

We shouldn't have underestimated the difficulty of implementing a new form of government, and it's not an easy thing to do, as we can see from our own country's history. The government made it seem like a relatively easy task, but it's not. 

In the 2004 presidential election, I was weighing my options, and one of my reasons for considering George Bush was to let him finish what he started. However, now that we've been in Iraq for so long, it's hard to justify continuing the war, especially considering the number of American casualties. It's a difficult decision, and I think we should try to see it through, but we also need to consider the astronomical number of casualties and whether it's worth risking more lives for a free democratic Iraq.

It's also interesting that we're not taking similar actions in other countries, like North Korea, which has weapons of mass destruction, but we're not targeting them. I think the real reason for invading Iraq is the oil issue and controlling resources. Another reason was the supposed presence of weapons of mass destruction, but they were never found. I don't think the US government is being truthful or thorough enough in its decision-making.

Let's hope the war ends soon and there's peace in Iraq, but unfortunately, it probably won't be that straightforward.

I'm still trying to figure out where to start with this, but I guess I'll just dive right in: I'm strongly in favor of gay marriage. I've always been, and I'm not really sure why I need to explain it, but I suppose I do. I think it's a deeply personal preference and something that's increasingly being shown to have a biological component, rather than being solely a product of societal influences. This makes it even harder to justify denying people the rights they deserve just because of something they can't control.

I've always believed that it's inhumane to withhold rights based on something that's beyond an individual's control. And, to be honest, I think it's rather hypocritical for politicians and the government to try to dictate what constitutes a marriage. Marriage is a personal, intimate relationship that affects individuals at a deeply personal level, not a state or government issue. In my neighborhood, there are a few openly gay couples who aren't married because they're not allowed to be, but they live their lives just like any other family would - they walk their dogs, go about their daily routines, and contribute to their community in the same ways as everyone else.

It's just ridiculous that the politicians are trying to impose their own twisted interpretation of marriage on everyone else. Bush's attempt to redefine marriage is nothing short of absurd. I've read and heard from countless credible sources that there's a chemical aspect to being gay, a predisposition that can't be changed by upbringing or environment. This biologically-based aspect is vastly different from sociological factors that might influence someone's choices.

To me, the most obvious issue with gay marriage is that it's a private matter, not something that should be subject to public scrutiny or federal approval. If a straight couple wants to get married, they can do it in secret, and it won't make the headlines. But if two gay people want to get married, it's front-page news. I think that's a clear indication that we need to treat marriage as a private, personal issue, rather than a matter of public policy.

Honestly, people often neglect the fact that anything posted online is now public domain. It's completely out in the open, and you can't retract it if you change your mind. As an RA, I've already dealt with this issue firsthand. When you share something, it can shape how others view you, and that's something to consider. If you're discussing sensitive topics like violence or threats, someone's bound to react. You can't hide that information, and it's not something you can just keep to yourself.

The internet is a broad platform that everyone can access. If you're friends with someone on Myspace or Facebook, you'll likely see their bulletin. It wasn't the school that received the bulletin in our case, but someone had access to it and shared it with the authorities. The school has a responsibility to act on potentially threatening situations to prevent harm.

It's difficult to know what to take seriously when some people post things as jokes or for a sociological experiment. We had a situation at school where someone overheard a comment and reported it. The person's online presence was reviewed, and some of the content they had posted was perceived as serious, even though it might have been intended as a joke.

When you post something online, you lose any expectation of privacy. If you don't want people to see it, you shouldn't post it. You can't dictate what others think or take seriously. I don't think it's a good idea for school officials to have social media accounts and be friends with students. However, if something's brought to their attention, they can't ignore it if it poses a potential threat.

I don't think schools should monitor phone conversations, texts, or IMs, but if a student reports a concern, it's a different story. As an RA, I don't even have a Facebook or Myspace account – I don't want to know about my residents' personal lives or see their photos online. It's not my place to know that information, and I certainly don't want the responsibility that comes with it.

Honestly, I think the war has been dragging on for far too long. At the beginning, the idea was to restore democracy in a country that was in dire need of it, but I think we've lost sight of that original purpose a long time ago. It seems like we're now fighting just to prove a point, to show the world that we're a superpower. 

I've always wondered if the motives behind the war were pure to begin with, especially considering the complicated history between George Bush's father and Saddam Hussein. If our goal was genuinely to bring democracy to a country that didn't have a fair political system, that would be a noble cause – as long as it wasn't motivated by personal interests. But I believe that's not the case. The war has dragged on for over a year, and I think we've already made our point in the first few months. Starting the war was a powerful statement in itself.

However, the fact that it's been going on for years is just ridiculous. If our initial intention was to liberate a country from tyranny, that's a just cause. But I think our reasons have been distorted and misconstrued over time. It seems like we're still fighting just for the sake of fighting, and we don't want to end the war without a clear victory. 

I truly believe it's time to bring this war to an end. Our government officials need to take responsibility for their own affairs, and I think that time has come. We've been bleeding our economy dry, spending billions of dollars on this war when we have our own problems to address, like poverty and internal issues that need funding. I think it's a drain on our economy for a cause that's long since been lost.

The amount of money being spent is staggering – billions and billions of dollars that could be better spent on our own internal problems, like public roads, education, and healthcare. It's disheartening to think that some of our own citizens are being killed in a war that we've lost sight of its purpose. I think that's a tragedy.

I had a question that I wanted to clarify, but I'm not sure where to start. It seems that someone was able to intervene in a situation because they found some information online that was quite revealing.

Honestly, it's pretty much expected that when you post stuff online, especially on sites like Myspace, it's going to be out there for everyone to see. You have to be a member to view someone's profile, but that's because you've essentially given permission for others to see it when you accepted their friend request. So, anytime you put information online, you have to be aware that a lot of people might see it.

I have to admit, in this case, I think it's a good thing that someone was able to see that information and prevent a potentially serious situation. However, I can see why it's tricky. It's not practical or fair to have someone constantly monitoring everyone's profiles just in case. It could be seen as discriminatory if they're only focusing on certain people.

I'm not sure how it would work in practice, but it's all about context. Was someone just browsing randomly or were they actively looking for something specific? If it's the former, it's a bit creepy, but if it's the latter, then maybe it's not such a bad thing.

Personally, I use Facebook, and it bothers me that there are people out there who could be seeing my information. I recall this one TV show where a guy demonstrated just how easy it is to get information online and use it to meet people. It's unnerving, to say the least. I've had people in my classes who I don't know, but they can figure out who I am and contact me through instant messaging. It's a delicate balance between sharing information and keeping it private.

I've tried to limit what I post online, but at the same time, I want to be able to connect with friends and classmates. It's a tough issue because you never know who might be looking at what. My roommate was telling me about how her high school banned Myspace, and it seemed a bit strange. I'm not sure how the school officials had the authority to do that. It's a complicated situation, and I'm still not entirely sure what to think about it.

i'm having trouble talking about the Iraq War, to be honest, because I feel like I'm jumping on a bandwagon 
I'm hesitant to admit that I was against it from the start, but it's not really relevant anymore 
The general consensus among people, except for those within the administration, is that the war was a bad idea, and I'm inclined to agree 
Looking at the polls - both in the US, Iraq, and globally - it's clear that around 75-80% of the population thinks the war was a mistake 
In fact, even a significant portion of US troops stationed in Iraq think it was a bad idea and that we should withdraw within a year 
The situation in Iraq has been a disaster from the get-go, and it's becoming increasingly clear that pulling out won't be easy either 
I think it's because of the huge cultural divide between the US and the Middle East, and the fact that we're trying to impose democracy in a region where it may not be welcomed 
I mean, Saddam was without a doubt a bad guy, but you can't just invade a country without considering the potential consequences 
It's like trying to impose Western values on a completely different culture 
I'm still not convinced that there's a good reason for us to stay in Iraq any longer than necessary 
I'm not sure I buy the administration's arguments for why we should stay, and I'm yet to hear a legitimate reason for extending our presence 
If they want to withdraw gradually over a year or so, I wouldn't have a problem with that, but I don't see why we can't just leave now 
It's clear that the Iraqi people would like us to leave, with around 80% wanting us out within a year and a quarter thinking we should leave immediately 
It makes sense to me that they might know better than we do, and if we ask them and they say yes, then it's on them if things go wrong 
If we leave, at least we can say we tried to do the right thing, even if it's not like we'll ever be seen as the "good guys" in the Middle East

i think there's still a lot of gender discrimination going on in the US.  i'm not just talking about women, though - it's also about the specific job or field someone's in.  overall, i feel like women have it tougher because there's this concept of a 'glass ceiling' where they're supposed to be equal but in reality, people often have a hard time accepting a woman in charge, even when she's qualified for the job.  it's because of how society's been raised for so long - people are used to men being in charge.  so, women might see a job they're qualified for, but the board won't promote them because it's not common to see women in upper management.  the same thing happens to men in industries like fashion or childcare - it's not common for men to be the primary caregivers, and people look down on them for it.  they're seen as the breadwinners and it's weird if they stay home to take care of the kids.

in fashion, it's even harder for men who are straight because people don't take them seriously.  it's like, if you're a man who's into fashion, people assume you're not really into it because it's not typically something men do.  they think you're just pretending to be like other guys who are into fashion.  it's the same with women in male-dominated fields - people assume they're not really good at it because they're women.

it's hard to change this mindset because society is set in its ways.  we've made progress, but it's slow.  we've come a long way since the 1800s, but it's still a slow process.  women are getting into higher positions and becoming CEOs, which is a good start.  and it's also becoming more acceptable for men to be stay-at-home dads.  but we still have to promote the good qualities of people who are being stereotyped.  we can't just force it, because people will resist.  we're at a good point now where we're starting to see some changes, but it takes time.

another thing is that people are discriminated against based on where they're from, not just their gender.  like, if you grew up on a farm and you're not a great speaker, but you're super intelligent and you work your way up to a CEO job, people might look down on you because of your accent.  or if you're a man and you're not a good writer, people might think you're not smart because of that.  it's not just about gender, it's about where you come from and how you speak.

So, I wanted to clarify how the law has changed on this issue. They've made some changes, apparently decriminalizing it, which means it's not as serious of an offense as it used to be. It's more like getting a traffic ticket, where you might get fined, but you won't be arrested and charged like before. Now, I know some people might worry about the future consequences of having a marijuana charge, even if it's decriminalized - it can still impact things like job interviews and other opportunities. On the other hand, there's a argument that arresting people, prosecuting them, and putting them through the system is really expensive. When you think about it, it adds up - arresting, booking, housing them, and then going through the court process, just to let them go. Plus, there's the cost of appointing a public defender, paying the judge, and having the state attorney's office handle the case. It all adds up, and it's not a small expense.

In places that are struggling financially, some officials might not be willing to make this change, even if it would free up a lot of money for other important things. But in cities like Denver, where people tend to be more open-minded, it makes sense to decriminalize marijuana. I think it's a good idea because it can free up funds for things like education, social programs for the elderly, and food programs for the homeless. It's not just about making marijuana freely available; it's about the financial benefits and the potential to use that money for good.

Of course, there are still concerns about making marijuana widely available. Some people might worry that it would be too easily accessible, like cigarettes sold in gas stations. That could lead to people smoking and driving, which is a problem. Marijuana is still stigmatized in many places, and having it out in the open might make people uncomfortable. 

I think in general, alcohol has more severe effects on motor skills, but marijuana can have a bigger impact on people's lifestyles. However, it's hard to make generalizations because everyone reacts differently to substances. Some people can handle them well, while others struggle with moderation. It's complex, and it's hard to make blanket statements about marijuana or any other substance.

Honestly, I'd agree with certain aspects of the Catholic Church, but I also see some inconsistency in their practices. They've maintained many traditions over time, which is good, but it's also essential to be open to change. On one hand, I think it's beneficial to draw from the past, but on the other hand, it's frustrating when it seems like the Church is inflexible and judgmental towards those who don't follow the doctrine precisely.

For instance, many Catholics believe in attending mass regularly, and they can be quite strict about how things are done. I feel that the Church sometimes looks down on people who don't conform to their expectations, and they also tend to be exclusive towards those with different faiths.

My personal experience with this is that my parents, who were an Episcopalian and a Catholic, respectively, couldn't get married in the Catholic Church because of my dad's non-Catholic background. This didn't really demonstrate tolerance for other faiths, which is a core Catholic teaching – to love others. However, the Church's actions often seem hypocritical in this regard.

I'm not convinced that allowing priests to marry would necessarily prevent pedophilic behavior. It's a separate issue, and I think people who engage in such acts would do so regardless of their marital status. It's not like having a spouse would somehow magically prevent them from harming children. So, I don't think allowing priests to be married would be a solution to this problem.

Well, I'm still undecided on this issue, but I think it's one of the most difficult topics we're dealing with right now. On one hand, the separation of church and state is a big part of it, and defining marriage in a way that doesn't offend anyone is a challenge in itself. I'm not sure if I think marriage should be viewed as a sacrament by the government or just a civil union between two people. If it's the former, then people might not get tax breaks or any special treatment if they're baptized, which seems unfair. On the other hand, if we view it as a civil union, then the government shouldn't be concerned with the details of the marriage, like whether it's a church wedding or not. It's just about two people who have committed to each other.

If that's the case, then the fact that gay couples can't get married because of the term "marriage" seems ridiculous. It's just a matter of two people getting a civil union, and that's it. If all the states could come to a sense of reason on this issue, then it should become a federal law. However, a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage is a bit much. It's not a huge issue that should warrant changing the constitution. It's not important enough to amend the constitution just to define or ban gay marriage.

Honestly, I don't think it's that simple.

I come from a Christian background, so I've always viewed homosexuality as a somewhat complex issue. Having a large circle of gay friends has made me think more deeply about it. While I don't entirely agree with the lifestyle, I believe it should be legalized. I think it's a matter that individual states should decide on their own, rather than relying on a national decision. This is because many states have different political leanings – some are more democratic, while others are more republican. If you live in a state with a democratic government, it's likely that they'll support gay marriage, and it's hard to disagree with their decision when you chose to live there. My stance is that homosexuals should have the same rights as heterosexuals, so each state should have the freedom to decide on legalization based on their own values. I think it's unfair for the president to impose a blanket ban on gay marriage across the entire country. Since he doesn't live in every state, it's not his call to decide how each state should govern itself. Plus, he'll be out of office soon, and future presidents will likely have their own views on the matter. It's better to let individual states make their own decisions, as they'll have to live with the consequences. They're the ones who will be directly impacted by the decision, not the president.

I'm not going to sugarcoat it, I completely disagree with the idea that schools shouldn't monitor a site like Myspace. Let me explain why. Myspace is a public platform, and as such, it's a place where users share content for anyone to see. If you post something on the internet, you have to understand that it's going to be viewed by others, including school officials. Even if you're not using the school's name, they could still access it from their homes.

In this case, if monitoring Myspace helps prevent a school shooting, I think it's perfectly fine. The school system's primary responsibility is to ensure the safety of its students, and if that means checking out student activity on Myspace, then so be it. It's not an invasion of privacy if it helps prevent harm.

Let's be real, if school officials are going on Myspace specifically to catch students misbehaving, that's a different story. That's an overreach. But if they're doing it to keep students safe, then I think it's a necessary measure. As long as it doesn't infringe on individual rights, I'm okay with it.

It's a lot easier to express yourself in writing, but when you're talking, it's a bit more challenging. Let me try to clarify. If you post something on Myspace and expect not to get in trouble, that's unrealistic. Everything you post online is public, and it can come back to haunt you.

Think about it like this: if you're a college student and you say something questionable in an email, it's going to follow you. Once something is on the internet, it's there forever. It's not like you can just erase it. If you're going to post something online, be prepared for the consequences.

In my opinion, students shouldn't be worried about school officials going on Myspace to catch them misbehaving. But if it leads to making the school system safer, then that's a different story. Other officials, like the police, should be allowed to monitor it too.

When parents drop their kids off at school, they expect it to be a safe environment. That's what school officials are trying to ensure. They're not just being nosy; they're trying to prevent something like a school shooting from happening. We had lockdown drills in my high school, and it was to prepare for worst-case scenarios.

It's the same principle here. The school officials were doing their job to prevent something bad from happening. They were making the school a safer place, and that's something we should appreciate.

That's my take on it. I don't have much more to add.

I've been hesitant to share my thoughts on the war, partly because I was personally affected by 9/11. At first, I was on board with the idea of going over there and making our presence known, but as time went on, I began to see the bigger picture. I think we rushed into the situation without a thorough plan, and that's exactly what backfired on us. 

Now, I'm strongly against the war. I don't think it's done anything meaningful, and I believe that as long as the people over there are fighting amongst themselves, they won't be a threat to us. But, unfortunately, 9/11 changed my perspective, and I've become somewhat apathetic towards their struggles. I sometimes feel like they're not even human, the way they wage war, and it's like they're not really trying to better their country. I think they just want us out, and that's it.

In hindsight, I think we went into this war with a lot of emotional baggage and a desire for revenge. President Bush's decision to declare war on Iraq was, at the time, somewhat understandable. We couldn't just let the attack go unpunished, but I do think we could have come up with a better plan. There was a lack of unity and a clear direction, which made things worse.

It's my honest opinion that we're not the ones to change those people. They're always going to be the way they are, and I don't think we're making enough progress to justify staying there.
